metadata.titleEn: One belt, one road, key node area, annual scale serial land cover data (2000-2020)
metadata.description: Remote sensing provides important technical means for large-scale surface monitoring. Thanks to the rich time series image data of Landsat TM, ETM+, and OLI/TIRS and the high-performance Google Earth Engine (GEE) cloud platform, large-scale surface coverage mapping has become possible. This data uses the three key nodes of Yangon, Hambantota, and Dhaka as the research area. With the help of the Google Earth Engine platform, the existing multiple sets of global land cover products and Landsat satellite series images are combined with multiple data fusion and time series change detection. Using methods such as machine learning, we have developed a high-temporal-spatial-consistent dataset of annual land cover changes with a resolution of 30 m from 2000 to 2020.
metadata.instructions: In .tif format, can be opened and analysed in ARCGIS and ENVI softwares.

background: High-spatiotemporal-resolution global multi-class land cover data play a critical role in the studies of biogeochemical cycles of the Earth system and global climate change. Among the existing open products, higher-resolution global multi-class land cover data are available for a single or short period of time, while annual ones have limited class, preventing longer-term analysis of land cover change in fine spatial detail. Global land cover change information is an important way to understand the complex interaction between human activities and global changes, and it is also the basic input for many ecosystem models, land surface process models, and atmospheric coupling models. With the emergence of numerous Earth observation satellites and the development of computer technology, remote sensing provides an important technical means for obtaining information on large-scale surface cover distribution and changes.
research objective: In this paper, with the support of the Google Earth Engine platform, we proposed a method composed of data fusion, change detection and machine learning based on existing global land cover maps in 2015, Landsat imagery and samples after manual interpretation to develop annual global land cover data (Annual Global Land Cover-2000-2015) from 2000 to 2015 at 30 m resolution. The study aims to develop a global annual land cover product with high resolution and long time series to meet the new needs of global change research and Earth system modeling.
methods: The basic idea of this study is: (1) to develop high-precision benchmark year (2015) land cover data; (2) to detect annual surface cover change areas through change detection methods; (3) to establish reliable classification models for land cover classification in change areas; (4) to generate annual data products by combining benchmark year land cover data and change area classification results. We used the Google Earth Engine (GEE) platform, based on Dempster-Shafer (D-S) evidence theory reasoning and decision-making, to integrate existing multiple land cover products to develop a reliable 2015 global 30m resolution land cover product. We then used Landsat series satellite imagery data, change detection methods, and machine learning classification algorithms to develop the global annual land cover data AGLC-2000-2015 from 2000 to 2015. The specific process of data product development is shown in Figure 1. The mapping is mainly divided into two parts: first, based on the D-S evidence theory, multiple global land cover data products are integrated to obtain reliable 2015 land cover products; using the 2015 land cover product as a benchmark, the 2000-2014 land cover maps are updated using change detection and random forest classification methods.
dataset: The land cover products used in this study include the following seven sets: Global land cover dataset Globeland30, global land cover dataset FROM-GLC, global fine surface coverage product dataset GLC-FCS30, global continuous urban land dynamic expansion and greening dataset GAUD, global forest change data GFC, global water body dataset JRCGSW, and global land cover dataset ESA CCI-LC. The 2000-2015 Landsat series images used in this paper come from the Landsat 5 TM (2000-2011), Landsat 7 ETM+ (2011-2013), and Landsat 8 OLI (2013-2015) sensors provided by the GEE platform, which have been atmospherically and terrain corrected to surface reflectance data.
findings: Our results show relatively high accuracy of AGLC-2000-2015. Mean overall accuracy and Kappa coefficient of global land cover product for the year 2015 (AGLC-2015) are 76.10% and 0.72, respectively. The overall accuracy and Kappa coefficient of the Random Forest classification model are 84.10% and 0.81, respectively. Urban area has increased substantially by an average of 195.96 km² in the Pearl River Delta of China, with 85% of the newly developed impervious surface encroaching on cropland. Selin Co lake responses significantly to the warming climate with expanding at a rate of 17.95 km², and the expansion is most pronounced in the north bank. Forest in the south part of Amazon has decreased by a total area of 46356.53 km², most of which is converted to cropland, showing forest destruction for cropland.

Definition.Question: How is machine learning utilized in land cover classification in remote sensing?
Definition.Answer: Machine learning is used to establish reliable classification models for land cover classification in areas where surface cover changes are detected. These models are crucial for generating annual land cover data products by combining benchmark year data with classification results in change areas.

Comparison.Question: How does the use of the Google Earth Engine platform for developing land cover data compare with traditional methods in terms of efficiency and scalability?
Comparison.Answer: The use of the Google Earth Engine platform allows for the integration of multiple land cover products and large-scale satellite imagery, offering efficient data processing and scalability. This contrasts with traditional methods that may require more manual input and limited computational resources for handling large volumes of data.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in outcomes when using machine learning algorithms like Random Forest compared to Dempster-Shafer evidence theory in land cover classification?
Comparison.Answer: Machine learning algorithms such as Random Forest provide high accuracy and classification reliability, as evidenced by the overall accuracy and Kappa coefficient. In contrast, the Dempster-Shafer evidence theory is used for integrating multiple data sources to establish a reliable benchmark year product, which serves as a foundational step before applying machine learning for ongoing classification.

Interpretation.Question: How might the integration of multiple land cover products using methods like Dempster-Shafer evidence theory influence the reliability and resolution of a dataset in the context of large-scale surface cover mapping?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of multiple land cover products using Dempster-Shafer evidence theory can enhance the reliability and resolution of a dataset by effectively combining various sources of land cover data to develop a more accurate and high-resolution product. This method allows for the creation of a reliable benchmark year data product, which is crucial for updating subsequent years’ data with change detection and classification methods.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways might the availability of high-spatiotemporal-resolution global multi-class land cover data affect studies of biogeochemical cycles and global climate change?
Interpretation.Answer: The availability of high-spatiotemporal-resolution global multi-class land cover data significantly enhances the ability to study biogeochemical cycles and global climate change by providing detailed insights into land cover changes over time. This data serves as a crucial input for ecosystem models, land surface process models, and atmospheric coupling models, enabling researchers to understand complex interactions between human activities and global environmental changes.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is Google Earth Engine significant for large-scale land cover mapping?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Google Earth Engine is significant for large-scale land cover mapping because it provides a high-performance cloud platform that enables the integration of multiple land cover products and facilitates the processing of vast amounts of time-series satellite imagery data. This technological capability supports the development of reliable and consistent land cover datasets over long time series.

Causal Consequence.Question: How could the use of machine learning algorithms contribute to the understanding of annual land cover changes from 2000 to 2020?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of machine learning algorithms can significantly contribute to understanding annual land cover changes by enabling the development of classification models that detect changes in surface cover. As demonstrated in the field, these algorithms, such as the Random Forest classification model, are key in updating land cover maps annually, thereby providing insights into changes over time with relatively high accuracy.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of employing remote sensing technologies like Landsat imagery in large-scale surface cover monitoring?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Employing remote sensing technologies such as Landsat imagery in large-scale surface cover monitoring can provide crucial data for understanding interactions between human activities and global changes. As indicated in the field, this approach allows for detailed analysis of land cover change over long periods, which is vital for global change research and Earth system modeling, resulting in products like the 2000-2020 annual land cover dataset.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the purpose of developing annual land cover data using data fusion, change detection, and machine learning techniques?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to create a global annual land cover product with high resolution and a long time series to meet new needs of global change research and Earth system modeling.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why integrate multiple existing global land cover products to develop a reliable 2015 land cover dataset?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Integrating multiple global land cover products using techniques like D-S evidence theory allows for the creation of a reliable benchmark year dataset which can be used as a foundation for updating and generating annual land cover maps in subsequent years.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are used to integrate multiple land cover data products to develop a reliable high-resolution land cover dataset?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The process involves using Dempster-Shafer (D-S) evidence theory reasoning and decision-making to integrate existing multiple land cover products. This integration helps in developing a reliable 2015 global 30m resolution land cover product.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is machine learning applied to classify land cover changes in areas identified through change detection methods?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Machine learning algorithms, specifically the Random Forest classification model, are used to classify land cover changes in identified areas. This is done after detecting annual surface cover change areas through change detection methods.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What is the approach to update historical land cover maps using benchmark year data and change detection methods?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The approach involves using 2015 land cover products as a benchmark and then updating the 2000-2014 land cover maps using change detection and random forest classification methods to generate annual data products.

Enablement.Question: What technological capabilities enable the development of a high-resolution land cover change dataset spanning two decades?
Enablement.Answer: The use of Landsat TM, ETM+, and OLI/TIRS series imagery data, coupled with the high-performance Google Earth Engine (GEE) cloud platform, enables the development of a high-resolution land cover change dataset spanning from 2000 to 2020.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of existing multiple global land cover products contribute to the reliability of land cover data at a finer resolution?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of multiple global land cover products using Dempster-Shafer evidence theory on the Google Earth Engine platform contributes to the development of a reliable 2015 global 30 m resolution land cover product, which serves as a benchmark for updating land cover maps in subsequent years.

Enablement.Question: What role do machine learning algorithms play in enhancing the accuracy of annual land cover classification in rapidly changing areas?
Enablement.Answer: Machine learning algorithms, specifically the Random Forest classification model, are used to establish reliable classification models for detecting annual surface cover changes and enhance the accuracy of annual land cover classification in rapidly changing areas.

Expectation.Question: Why are high-resolution global multi-class land cover datasets typically limited to short periods or single years?
Expectation.Answer: Higher-resolution global multi-class land cover data are usually available for a single or short period of time due to the limited class and the challenges in maintaining consistent accuracy and detail over extended timeframes. The complexity of integrating multiple datasets and the computational demands of processing long-term, high-resolution data also contribute to these limitations.

Expectation.Question: Why might the integration of multiple global land cover products be necessary for developing a reliable benchmark year dataset?
Expectation.Answer: Integrating multiple global land cover products is necessary to develop a reliable benchmark year dataset because it allows for the combination of different strengths and minimizes weaknesses present in individual datasets. This integration helps achieve a more accurate representation of land cover by leveraging diverse sources, methodologies, and classifications.

Expectation.Question: Why is machine learning used in conjunction with change detection methods for land cover classification in change areas?
Expectation.Answer: Machine learning is used alongside change detection methods for land cover classification in change areas because it provides robust algorithms capable of handling complex data patterns and can improve classification accuracy. Machine learning models, such as Random Forest, can effectively learn from existing data to predict changes, making them essential for updating and refining land cover maps.

Judgmental.Question: How do you evaluate the effectiveness of integrating multiple global land cover products for improving the accuracy of land cover maps?
Judgmental.Answer: The integration of multiple global land cover products using Dempster-Shafer evidence theory helps develop a reliable 2015 global 30m resolution land cover product, which forms a strong benchmark for updating annual maps. This approach seems effective as it combines diverse datasets to improve accuracy, as evidenced by achieving a mean overall accuracy of 76.10% and a Kappa coefficient of 0.72 for the 2015 global land cover product.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about how change detection methods contribute to understanding land cover changes over time.
Assertion.Answer: Change detection methods are essential for identifying areas where surface cover has changed from year to year. By detecting these changes, researchers can update land cover maps and track changes in land cover classes, which helps in understanding the dynamics of land use and cover over time.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how machine learning classification algorithms improve the accuracy of land cover data.
Assertion.Answer: Machine learning classification algorithms, like the Random Forest model, enhance the accuracy of land cover data by establishing reliable classification models for areas where changes are detected. These algorithms utilize existing data and samples to classify land cover types, resulting in higher accuracy and reliability of the annual land cover datasets.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the data collection techniques used in developing annual global land cover data at 30 m resolution from 2000 to 2015.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection techniques involve using existing global land cover maps, Landsat imagery, and samples after manual interpretation. The process includes data fusion, change detection, and machine learning. The Google Earth Engine platform is utilized to integrate multiple land cover products to develop reliable 2015 global land cover data. Change detection methods and random forest classification algorithms are used to update land cover maps from 2000-2014.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential datasets that could be used for expanding or refining land cover change analysis.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets for expanding or refining land cover change analysis include the Global land cover dataset Globeland30, FROM-GLC, GLC-FCS30, GAUD, GFC, JRCGSW, and ESA CCI-LC. Additionally, Landsat series images from the Landsat 5 TM, Landsat 7 ETM+, and Landsat 8 OLI sensors are used, which have been atmospherically and terrain corrected to surface reflectance data.
